commit.message:
net: make it possible to connect to CJDNS addresses

Connecting to CJDNS addresses works without a proxy, just like
connecting to an IPv6 address. Thus adapt `CService::GetSockAddr()` to
retrieve the `struct sockaddr*` even for `CService::IsCJDNS()` objects.

verification.payload:
tree a8ea7a810997f64c3cca243f4473bff751ebacd8
parent 23ae7931be50376fa6bda692c641a3d2538556ee
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1631204357 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635946869 +0100

net: make it possible to connect to CJDNS addresses

Connecting to CJDNS addresses works without a proxy, just like
connecting to an IPv6 address. Thus adapt `CService::GetSockAddr()` to
retrieve the `struct sockaddr*` even for `CService::IsCJDNS()` objects.

commit.message:
net: use -proxy for connecting to the CJDNS network

If `-proxy` is given, then also use it for connecting to the CJDNS
network.

verification.payload:
tree d42da2beaf19983b52ace641f4a2762937578899
parent aedd02ef2750329019d5698b14b17d67c5a563ad
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1632220011 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635946874 +0100

net: use -proxy for connecting to the CJDNS network

If `-proxy` is given, then also use it for connecting to the CJDNS
network.

commit.message:
net: recognize CJDNS from ParseNetwork()

This allows to use "cjdns" as an argument to the `getnodeaddresses` RPC
and to the `-onlynet=` parameter.

verification.payload:
tree 2facad8c05428161f9e2c920c47165f533432b24
parent de01e312b333b65b09c8dc72f0cea6295ab8e43f
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1632323191 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635946874 +0100

net: recognize CJDNS from ParseNetwork()

This allows to use "cjdns" as an argument to the `getnodeaddresses` RPC
and to the `-onlynet=` parameter.

-        # Test for the absence of onion and I2P addresses.

         # Test invalid arguments.

commit.message:
net: introduce a new config option to enable CJDNS

CJDNS is set up in the host OS, outside of the application. When the
routing is configured properly then connecting to fc00::/8 results in
connecting to the CJDNS network.

Introduce an option so that Bitcoin Core knows whether this is the case.

verification.payload:
tree 387efc53d27df0c535d0bfd39f2b16373f61916e
parent 78f456c57677e6a3a839426e211078ddf0b3e194
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1631202011 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635947928 +0100

net: introduce a new config option to enable CJDNS

CJDNS is set up in the host OS, outside of the application. When the
routing is configured properly then connecting to fc00::/8 results in
connecting to the CJDNS network.

Introduce an option so that Bitcoin Core knows whether this is the case.

commit.message:
net: recognize CJDNS addresses as such

In some cases addresses come from an external source as a string or as a
`struct sockaddr_in6`, without a tag to tell whether it is a private
IPv6 or a CJDNS address. In those cases interpret the address as a CJDNS
address instead of an IPv6 address if `-cjdnsreachable` is set and the
seemingly-IPv6-address belongs to `fc00::/8`. Those external sources are:

* `-externalip=`
* `-bind=`
* UPnP
* `getifaddrs(3)` (called through `-discover`)
* `addnode`
* `connect`
* incoming connections (returned by `accept(2)`)

verification.payload:
tree 28a81daab7dda4beb6920516290dd365b41c8ab4
parent e6890fcb440245c9a24ded0b7af46267453433f1
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1631530925 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635947930 +0100

net: recognize CJDNS addresses as such

In some cases addresses come from an external source as a string or as a
`struct sockaddr_in6`, without a tag to tell whether it is a private
IPv6 or a CJDNS address. In those cases interpret the address as a CJDNS
address instead of an IPv6 address if `-cjdnsreachable` is set and the
seemingly-IPv6-address belongs to `fc00::/8`. Those external sources are:

* `-externalip=`
* `-bind=`
* UPnP
* `getifaddrs(3)` (called through `-discover`)
* `addnode`
* `connect`
* incoming connections (returned by `accept(2)`)

commit.message:
test: remove default argument of feature_proxy.py:node_test()

The default bool argument makes it harder to read because the last but
one argument is also bool. Pass all of them as named arguments to
increase readability.

Another bool argument will be added to indicate whether to test CJDNS.

Co-authored-by: Jon Atack <jon@atack.com>

     - `-proxy` (proxy everything)
     - `-onion` (proxy just onions)

+    - `-cjdnsreachable`
 - Proxy configurations to test on proxy side,
     - support no authentication (other proxy)

 addnode connect to IPv6
 addnode connect to onion

+addnode connect to a CJDNS address
 
 - Test getnetworkinfo for each node
 """
@@ -58,7 +60,7 @@

-        self.num_nodes = 4
+        self.num_nodes = 5
         self.setup_clean_chain = True

+            ['-listen', f'-proxy={self.conf1.addr[0]}:{self.conf1.addr[1]}','-proxyrandomize=1',
+                '-cjdnsreachable']
         ]
         if self.have_ipv6:
             args[3] = ['-listen', f'-proxy=[{self.conf3.addr[0]}]:{self.conf3.addr[1]}','-proxyrandomize=0', '-noonion']
@@ -114,7 +118,7 @@ def network_test(self, node, addr, network):
             if peer["addr"] == addr:
                 assert_equal(peer["network"], network)
 
-    def node_test(self, node, *, proxies, auth, test_onion):

@@ -162,6 +166,21 @@ def node_test(self, node, *, proxies, auth, test_onion):
             rv.append(cmd)
             self.network_test(node, addr, network=NET_ONION)
 
+        if test_cjdns:
+            addr = "[fc00:1:2:3:4:5:6:7]:8888"

+                assert_equal(cmd.username, None)
+                assert_equal(cmd.password, None)
+            rv.append(cmd)

+
         addr = "node.noumenon:8333"
         self.log.debug(f"Test: outgoing DNS name connection through node for address {addr}")
         node.addnode(addr, "onetry")
@@ -182,17 +201,17 @@ def run_test(self):

             proxies=[self.serv1, self.serv1, self.serv1, self.serv1],

             proxies=[self.serv2, self.serv2, self.serv2, self.serv2],
-            auth=True, test_onion=True)
+            auth=True, test_onion=True, test_cjdns=False)
         # Check that credentials as used for -proxyrandomize connections are unique
         credentials = set((x.username,x.password) for x in rv)
         assert_equal(len(credentials), len(rv))
@@ -201,7 +220,12 @@ def run_test(self):
             # proxy on IPv6 localhost
             self.node_test(self.nodes[3],
                 proxies=[self.serv3, self.serv3, self.serv3, self.serv3],
-                auth=False, test_onion=False)
+                auth=False, test_onion=False, test_cjdns=False)
+
+        # -proxy=unauth -proxyrandomize=1 -cjdnsreachable
+        self.node_test(self.nodes[4],
+            proxies=[self.serv1, self.serv1, self.serv1, self.serv1],

         def networks_dict(d):
             r = {}
@@ -266,6 +290,21 @@ def networks_dict(d):
             assert_equal(n3['i2p']['reachable'], False)
             assert_equal(n3['cjdns']['reachable'], False)
 
+        n4 = networks_dict(self.nodes[4].getnetworkinfo())
+        assert_equal(NETWORKS, n4.keys())
+        for net in NETWORKS:
+            if net == NET_I2P:
+                expected_proxy = ''

+                expected_proxy = '%s:%i' % (self.conf1.addr)
+                expected_randomize = True
+            assert_equal(n4[net]['proxy'], expected_proxy)
+            assert_equal(n4[net]['proxy_randomize_credentials'], expected_randomize)
+        assert_equal(n4['onion']['reachable'], True)
+        assert_equal(n4['i2p']['reachable'], False)
+        assert_equal(n4['cjdns']['reachable'], True)
+
 
 if __name__ == '__main__':
     ProxyTest().main()

commit.message:
net: take CJDNS into account in CNetAddr::GetReachabilityFrom()

This way `GetLocal()` will pick our CJDNS address for a CJDNS peer.

verification.payload:
tree fffb8f465effc3fa2915af961b4e4137add70ed7
parent 9b43b3b257a00f777538fcc6e2550702055a1488
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1631262490 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635947932 +0100

net: take CJDNS into account in CNetAddr::GetReachabilityFrom()

This way `GetLocal()` will pick our CJDNS address for a CJDNS peer.

commit.message:
net: relay CJDNS addresses even if we are not connected to CJDNS

This will help with propagation, so that multi-homed nodes can learn
CJDNS addresses outside of the CJDNS network.

verification.payload:
tree 7212b84b5da88119279a34b04acf1001d850498b
parent d96f8d304c872b21070245c1b6aacc8b1f5da697
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1631202672 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635947933 +0100

net: relay CJDNS addresses even if we are not connected to CJDNS

This will help with propagation, so that multi-homed nodes can learn
CJDNS addresses outside of the CJDNS network.

commit.message:
net: take the first 4 random bits from CJDNS addresses in GetGroup()

CJDNS addresses start with constant 8 bits, so in order to account for
the first 4 random ones, we must take the first 12. Otherwise the entire
CJDNS network will belong to one group.

verification.payload:
tree 72d1abd2ff13bf28afa8bd3b4243de663254787e
parent 29ff79c0a2a95abf50b78dd2be6ead2abeeaec9f
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1631195172 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635947934 +0100

net: take the first 4 random bits from CJDNS addresses in GetGroup()

CJDNS addresses start with constant 8 bits, so in order to account for
the first 4 random ones, we must take the first 12. Otherwise the entire
CJDNS network will belong to one group.

commit.message:
contrib: recognize CJDNS seeds as such

An IPv6 address from fc00::/8 could be either from the CJDNS network or
from a private-unroutable-reserved segment of IPv6. A seed node with
such an address must be from the CJDNS network, otherwise other peers
will not be able to connect to it.

verification.payload:
tree b8553180d9d895d90f930f5ceb2918d4b8db59b2
parent f9c28330a0e77ed077f342e4669e855b3e6b20a1
author Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1631194244 +0200
committer Vasil Dimov <vd@FreeBSD.org> 1635947935 +0100

contrib: recognize CJDNS seeds as such

An IPv6 address from fc00::/8 could be either from the CJDNS network or
from a private-unroutable-reserved segment of IPv6. A seed node with
such an address must be from the CJDNS network, otherwise other peers
will not be able to connect to it.

files.patch:
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@ def name_to_bip155(addr):
             raise ValueError(f'Invalid I2P {vchAddr}')
     elif '.' in addr: # IPv4
         return (BIP155Network.IPV4, bytes((int(x) for x in addr.split('.'))))
-    elif ':' in addr: # IPv6
+    elif ':' in addr: # IPv6 or CJDNS
         sub = [[], []] # prefix, suffix
         x = 0
         addr = addr.split(':')
@@ -77,7 +77,14 @@ def name_to_bip155(addr):
                 sub[x].append(val & 0xff)
         nullbytes = 16 - len(sub[0]) - len(sub[1])
         assert((x == 0 and nullbytes == 0) or (x == 1 and nullbytes > 0))
-        return (BIP155Network.IPV6, bytes(sub[0] + ([0] * nullbytes) + sub[1]))
+        addr_bytes = bytes(sub[0] + ([0] * nullbytes) + sub[1])
+        if addr_bytes[0] == 0xfc:
+            # Assume that seeds with fc00::/8 addresses belong to CJDNS,
+            # not to the publicly unroutable "Unique Local Unicast" network, see
+            # RFC4193: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4193#section-8
+            return (BIP155Network.CJDNS, addr_bytes)
+        else:
+            return (BIP155Network.IPV6, addr_bytes)
     else:
         raise ValueError('Could not parse address %s' % addr)
